questionListItems.title: How many classes does BBSS have for Sec 1 cohort?

answer.body: You may refer to this page on our school website for more information - https://www.bukitbatoksec.moe.edu.sg/about-us/Admissions/

questionListItems.title: Should I select Bukit Batok Secondary School (BBSS) as one of my choices if I just met the minimum requirements of the indicative score range?

answer.body: The indicative score range is calculated based on the range of T-score of the current year Sec 1 cohort. It should be noted that the Cut Off Point (COP) varies from year to year. One way to go about choosing a school would be to list down schools that you are keen to join and check whether their COP is near your T-score.

questionListItems.title: My child qualified for Posting Group 3, can he/she apply for Posting Group 2 in Bukit Batok Secondary School?

answer.body: Your child will not be able to apply to join a Posting Group 2 course in a Secondary School.

questionListItems.title: Does BBSS offer Pure Literature at Upper Secondary?

answer.body: Yes, BBSS does offer Pure Literature at the Upper Secondary level. For more information on the list of subjects, electives and programmes offered at BBSS. you may also refer to the following MOE website.

questionListItems.title: Will students be offered humanities at a more demanding level from Secondary 2?

answer.body: Secondary 2 students in posting groups 1 and 2 will have the opportunity to take Humanities subjects ( Geography, History and Literature) at a more demanding level if they meet the subject-based criteria in Secondary 1. They should also possess a positive attitude towards learning and a strong commitment to offer the subject at a more demanding level.

questionListItems.title: Will students be allowed to switch to a more demanding stream or take subjects at a more demanding level if they do well after they join the school?

answer.body: Students may be offered subject(s) at a more demanding level or switch to a more demanding stream if they meet the criteria at the end of the year of study.

questionListItems.title: How much time does a student need to spend on CCA each week?

answer.body: The frequency and duration of the CCA sessions vary from one to another. These are likely to increase when the students are preparing for competitions. Generally, our CCA days are on Monday and Wednesday, with approximately 3 hours for each session.

questionListItems.title: How is CCA allocated to each student?

answer.body: CCA allocation is based on students' choices and talents and available vacancies. CCA trials will be conducted for Secondary 1 students, more information will be briefed in term 1 of the school year.

questionListItems.title: How many assessments will a student have for each subject for a year?

answer.body: As announced by the Ministry of Education (MOE) in Sept 2018, all students will not have more than one weighted assessment per subject per school term 1 â€“ 3, and an End of Year Examination in Term 4. The school also monitors the academic progress of students using other non-weighted assessments, such as project work and presentations.

questionListItems.title: How does the school support students to cope with the demands of the academic programmes?

answer.body: Support structures such as remedial lessons and consultations are provided for students when necessary.

questionListItems.title: What is the indicative cut-off score range for 2024 Sec 1 admission?

answer.body: You may find the information on the following MOE website.

questionListItems.title: What is the indicative cut-off score range for 2024 Sec 1 admission?

answer.body: You may find the information on the following site.

questionListItems.title: Will my child/ward continue to be offered SBB in a subject offered throughout his/her stay with the school?

answer.body:
Students offered SBB are encouraged to continue with SBB until the end of Secondary 2 regardless of the grades achieved, as it takes time for students to adjust to the higher level of rigour.


At the end of Secondary 2, SBB students who meet the criteria will continue to be offered SBB at upper secondary level by the school. In consultation with their subject teachers and a review of their examination results, students and their parents can also make the final decision to continue or drop the subject, as long as they are aware of the possible impact in terms of post-secondary progression.

questionListItems.title: What is the advantage of taking Subject Based Banding (SBB)?

answer.body: SBB provides greater flexibility in subject offering at lower secondary levels, to better cater to the strengths of students in different subjects.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find more information about PDLP in BBSS?

answer.body: You may refer to the PDLP Parent Engagement Site here: https://go.gov.sg/bbsspdlp.
